text: Microbial respiration of phosphate might be the cause of such “ghostly” apparitions.
Nevertheless, some anaerobic decomposers use phosphate as a terminal electron acceptor, reducing it to phosphine.
The absence of fully reduced phosphorus in ecosystems may be due to the fact spontaneous combustion in the presence of oxygen.
Phosphorus is a fundamental element of nucleic acids, phospholipids, and phosphorylated proteins.
Unlike sulfur and nitrogen, which are found in several different oxidation states, phosphorus is cycled mainly in the fully oxidized state of phosphate (Fig. 22.19).
In marshes and graveyards, where extensive decomposition occurs, phosphine emanates from the ground, where it ignites with a green glow.
